transcription.text: My name is Greg.
Might know me online as Greg the Greek.
Today I'm going to be talking about towards E2 developer tooling.
Basically, you know, how are you going to go from E2 and is it going to work?
And what are we going to do about it?
So, I'm not going to preview here.
So quickly, who's changed -- oh, geez.
Who's changed?
We're an R&D protocol shop out of Toronto.
About 26 people, mainly in Toronto and a little bit distributed.
We're working on an E2 client called load star.
And who I am?
I'm one of the co-founders of VP engineering.
You can find me, Greg the Greek, just about on everything.
And yeah, so what is load star?
So load star is a TypeScript and assembly script, basically E2 ecosystem.
We're building just about everything that we can in there.
And we're going to be able to do that.

And it does like 13,000 downloads on the little used packages
on the GitHub downloads thing, which is like,
that's a lot of people depending on one small piece of software
within the larger context of the ecosystem.
So just to highlight the example, we have a block in ETH 1.
And we don't really have a one-to-one equivalent
because we have two types of blocks in ETH 2.
So that's a problem.
We also have shards.
Shards don't exist.
So your ETH 1, I don't know what you would do there.
What would ETHers do when you say, get block?
Where do you go?
There's two blocks.
And there's also many shards.
And then we have execution environments.
I don't even want to touch that.
And I won't be touching that today because that's something
else.
But to highlight my point is there's
so many discrepancies that the APIs will never line up,
and they won't.
But there's some things we can do.
And there's some clever things we can do.
So something I've been thinking about as an interim solution--
and obviously, this is not great.
The more I've been talking about a lot of teams,
especially Truffle, has been like, no, they want--
they're happy to do a proper spaked in solution.
But something interim that we could do with ETHers,
what we typically do is you pass in the network
you want to use.
And what we can actually do is we can create an adapter
that sits right on in the outside
and wraps all the requests.
And basically, the idea behind that slide, you think?
No.
And basically, the idea behind that
is something that we did at ChainSafe
with something called Ethermint from the Cosmos ecosystem,
where we made the EVM work on top of Tendermint.
But naturally, again, it's kind of a similar situation.
They don't line up.
But we had to make sure that all the developer tooling worked
right out of the gate so that it was playing in Ethereum.
Because otherwise, why would you use it?
So what we did was we basically added this layer in front
that every time an API request came into the EVM,
or in this case, it would be like when it hits
Beacon Chain or AO, whatever is there.
We're basically looking at it and then translating
to whatever we think makes the most sense from that side.
So we can do that with the Beacon Chain with this.
So chances are you have a contract.
You're saying, hey, I want to look up this contract.
You have to get routed to a shard,
because that's where your contract's going to be living.
And you're going to have to do it that way.
So we can just take a generic request from the standard ETH1
API and like re-wrap it and pop it back out.
That works.
It's not great.
That would mean every client team would have to go and adopt
this, like an interface sitting in front of their current,
whatever we end up making these two API,
whether it's JSON, RPC, whatever.
It does the job.
It's not great.
We could also integrate directly into the providers.
We could directly put it into ETH3s.
Again, not the optimal solution.
Well, this is something we're thinking about.
Ideally, we're going to have to do some sort of a ground up
rewrite on our providers.
And if we can do it from the providers perspective,
then we actually save ourselves.
As long as the providers maintain the same API format,
and then we're just doing a lot of magic in behind,
we actually won't have to rewrite a lot of our dev tooling.
And dev teams can continue to operate as they did before.
Naturally, it'd be nice to get some native ETH2 tooling.
But to help ease the transition over,
this is one that's something along this line
will probably have to be the best case we can do.
Otherwise, we just won't have anything ready by the time
ETH2 launches.
And there's no point in spending resources doing twice.
So that's my little provider, Shil.
And I'm happy to talk about this a lot more after.
Something else that's kind of interesting--
unless it's funny-- it's like, maybe we can solve it
after 30 years, but we won't.
Is the intersection of like, like clients and developer
tooling and how we can actually potentially
make smarter developers?
And by this, I mean like more on the front end,
the D app side.
Because right now, we spend a lot of time--
a lot of the ways we do things, we do a lot polling.
For instance, a lot of developers
are like, go and pull the chain like a million times over
and a million times over.
And then if they're hitting in fear,
you're getting like, you're bombarding in fear
with thousands of requests.
It's not a great solution.
But moving forward, because light clients are becoming
our first class citizens in ETH2,
which means we actually can use this as like a powerful tool
to help us not exhaust resources and actually utilize only
what we need to serve our D apps or serve whatever
the application is moving forward.
So I've naively put-- we're still working on this.
And it's kind of like, we're trying
to think of a new way to reshape the way we interact
with the chain.
I don't want to go too deep on light clients,
but basically the idea is you subscribe to a shard that you
want, or a subset of shards that you want.
And you only get the relevant data that you need.
Very lightly put.
And something that we can do here is the current model
and flow in ETH1 is that the website connects to the provider.
The provider then hits a full node.
Has to-- the full node has to like basically index the whole
thing to find what exact information you need,
and then returns it.
Very slow, very cumbersome.
With light clients, what we can do is we actually
can put the burden back on the website,
or the client or the browser itself.
And this is kind of interesting, because what we can do
is we can do one of two things.
We can say, when you go onto a website,
we can look for-- now I know a lot of people are going
to be like, oh, he shouldn't be injecting like web 3
into the browser.
But we're not going to talk about that right now.
Let's just make a naive assumption.
So is there like an ETH2 object in the browser?
If there is, we can assume that there's some sort of a provider
already existing, and there's like potentially a plugin
like Metamask.
In that case, Metamask in this instance
would be hosting a light client actually within the plugin.
This allows then the website to go and say, hey,
I need you to subscribe to this shard for me,
and then start persisting and maintaining the data.
And then once the data is requested,
the website uses it as it's going.
While that's happening, we can actually
cache that shard data in a cookie local storage,
or even if it's a plugin in the plugin state.
And alternatively, if we make our providers smart,
we can then actually have the website itself.
If the user doesn't have a plugin,
we have the website itself actually spin up a light client.
And this is because we will be able to do this simply
because we've got languages compiling to Wasm,
but also load stars like whole goal
is to have a light client that runs in the browser.
That's native to the browser and works.
So with that, we can actually kind of exploit the browser
to its full scalabilities so that the burden doesn't go
on a centralized service like Infira.
And don't get me wrong, Infira is amazing.
We have to lot to thank for them,
but let's try and take the burden away from them if we can.
And a scheme something like this would definitely help
solve a lot of those issues and could potentially change
the way we develop and serve data.
Yeah, that's then under my talk.
Let's chat afterwards if you are a tooling team
'cause there's a lot to kind of discuss here.
It's still pretty early, but there's things
that we need to start talking about now.
I know there's a lot of pain points in the current API
and the current way ETH1 works in regards
to the JSON RPC API.
And we have an opportunity to kind of learn from our mistakes,
reshape it from the beginning, and basically,
make it as optimal as we can right out of the gate.
So thank you.
And you can contact me here.
